newsitem.title: INDIA: Gulf Air, Kuwait Airways told to sell stakes in Je.
newsitem.headline: Gulf Air, Kuwait Airways told to sell stakes in Je.

text.p: India's Civil Aviation Ministry has given Gulf Air and Kuwait Airways until October 15 to sell their 20-percent stakes in private Indian carrier Jet Airways, a Jet spokesman said on Saturday.
"We have been given time by the Civil Aviation Ministry till October 15 to disinvest," a Jet Airways spokesman told Reuters.

The cabinet in April barred foreign airlines from holding equity stakes in the domestic aviation sector. The policy effectively scuttled a proposed $600-million tie-up between Singapore Airlines Ltd and India's Tata group.
The cabinet also upheld a rule limiting foreign firms which are not airlines to 40 percent equity stakes in domestic airlines.
"The process has already started. The board has already decided to disinvest 40 percent foreign equity," the spokesman said.
Gulf Air and Kuwait Airways each own a 20-percent stake in Jet Airways and are the only foreign airlines with equity stakes in an Indian carrier.
Asked who will buy the stakes owned by the two foreign airlines, the spokesman said: "That process is not known at the moment." There was no estimate of the value of the stakes.
India's Civil Aviation Ministry has recently come under attack from investors for its flip-flop stance on key policy issues.
"Even now it is not a clear and lucid policy," H.K. Malik, an aviation analyst, told Reuters.
Local newspapers reported last week that the Civil Aviation Ministry was considering a review of the policy announced in April.
The main opposition Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party on Thursday attacked the government for a plan that envisaged foreign airlines taking equity in domestic carriers.
But a Civil Aviation Ministry spokeswoman on Saturday denied the newspaper reports and allegations by the BJP.
There is no rethinking in the government on the recent cabinet decision barring foreign airlines from holding equity stakes in the domestic aviation sector, the spokeswoman said.
"All reports to this effect appearing in a section of the press appear to be in the nature of kite flying," she added.
